threads.com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

For context, I released Wales to play as them without nation-ruining England. I got France (with Burgundy), Denmark, and some Irish minors to support my independence. Fired off the independence war and we overran England's allies of Aragorn and Portugal. Then two horrible things happened: Muscovy attacked my ally Denmark and Austria attacked France. I had tons of ducats to build up and prepare for round 2, but all my allies went into debt spirals and weren't going to join me for another war against England. >>1270972
>Saving is fairly quick, but sometimes it becomes extremely, extremely slow out of nowhere while I'm playing and the slowness doesn't go away until I restart the game.
Suddenly slowness that doesn't go away until you restart is typically down to memory leaks.

Take a look at your mod list, big mods that make heavy use of lazylib are typically the worst offenders for memory leaks. Ironshell, UAF and Nexerlin are the three most popular culprits, try disabling UAF and Ironshell, there's a special mention for Kyeltziv Technocracy/Dronelib which, while not as popular, leaks like a sieve.

A temporary fix for your problem is to increase the amount of ram (VMParam), it won't make the problem disappear, it just means you can play for longer before the slowdown begins. Upgrading to Java 8 is more cumbersome solution but works better in the long term.

>>1270994
>It's the shitty fossilized version of Java the game runs on.
The Java runs fine, as evidence by the base game being stable. The problem is shitty coding on the part of modders and their inability/unwillingness to fix their leaks. Remember when Alex included a leak detector and the discord community threw a fit because it kept saying their mods had leaks, their solution, get Alex to disable the leak detector rather than fix their shit.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
is a grand STRATEGY GAME that I have been developing, it's not "off-topic", even if it isn't complete.
Set in pseudo-Europe and inspired by Imperator, it seeks not to be another map painter but an empire manager, with a focus on:
>resource management (you need wood to build ships, grain to feed pops, wool to prevent them from freezing, etc)
>pop management (who all have their wealth)
>character management
>closed economy with prepaid-model
>anti-omniscience (limited information, e.g. you don't know many troops other countries have)
>faction management (all characters belong to a faction, and everything you do impact the faction's loyalty, if you go to war against the faction's beloved country, they might revolt against you)
>army management (army depletes as you advance because you have to leave troops behind to garrison)
>making the world evolve (you turn forests into farmlands, build bridges over rivers, convert villages to cities)

>I'm a bit afraid of overwhelming the player with information.
I don't think that's really something to be worried about. A good grand strat UI, like Victoria 2's, actually puts a ton of information in front of the player, especially the topbar. This might seem bad, but it's actually really good. The thing is, all this information is required information. The player's going to have to learn and use it at some point, so the question is whether it will be easily accessible but very front-loaded, or if it will be buried deep in some sub-menu, hard to access, but there's less on screen at any point in time.

So if you go the latter option, yeah, it'll be a bit less intimidating to a new player, but it'll also be harder for them to learn because information is hidden, and it will be tremendously frustrating to use when the player wants information. Conversely the former option might be a bit intimidating, but it's also really convenient once you have the hang of it.

I don't think your UI is overwhelming in terms of information provided (actually, you could probably make it denser and fit a lot more information for display, but as it is now, it does look quite usable), but I would probably go with the wood panels you mentioned. I find the stone background on the topbar makes the text a little bit difficult to read.

Pic related is what I mean. Consider the population button. 9.01M(4.32k) isn't really descriptive to glance at and not friendly for a new player. But once you know it means total pops and pop growth this month, it's really convenient and easy to read. You don't need a label saying that it's the population and growth, which would just take up space and, while useful for a new player, would be useless for most of the time a player is playing the game. National focus, militancy, consciousness, all just have little icon labels rather than text.

last_replies.com:
One thing that sets the game apart from the state-centrist strategy game is the fact you don't play as a state or character.
You play as a king-maker, but your influence is limited based on your "Sway". Essentially, Sway is something you gain from serving the state, and it is used to overrule the wishes.
Example.
>Your king is a part of the religion faction, he wishes to attack infidels, but avoid war with religious brethren
>therefore as long as he is the monarch, going in war against the infidels will be free, and you actually gain Sway from it
>in contrast, attacking brethen requirest certain amount of Sway, and you will lose way for doing it

Similarly, you can use sway to replace the country's ruler with someone whose interest aligns with yours.

I reckon completely transform the gameplay. In games like EU4, you can do whatever want, but here you actually have to serve your state in order to bring it out of its comfort gone.

>>1270968
It's a bit of a race, but it's manageable. Typically you'll be buying resources from Archie so you can quickly claim interesting islands, even if you'll only start building on them at a much later point.
Medium AIs are fairly easy to pacify with gifts and compliments, so you shouldn't be going to war unless you want to.
Expert AI is much more aggressive and expansive, personally I don't enjoy playing them as I find it's too much. As the name suggests, it's best to wait until you have a good knowledge of production chains and layouts so you don't waste time getting what you need.
You will need to use a lot of resources towards the military, production chains you can completely bypass on easy/no AI, and while you can farm resources on pirate ships once you have a somewhat decent fleet, it will hinder your development.

On a personal note, I don't think anno is a very good/interesting wargame. War generally boils down to who has the better fleet (which makes sense, but there's no real strategy to it). Anno really shines as a citybuilder and management game, whereas playing it like a classic rts feels lacklustre. Still, try a game with maybe 1 medium AI and 1 Easy and see hot it goes. If you feel like the pressure is too high, you probably won't enjoy harder AIs

>Thank you for the detailed information.
My pleasure. I've translated his entire biography here with annotations. https://daolun.substack.com/p/translation-jiang-wei-sanguozhi-443

>Didn't this plan fail because he underestimated the size of the Wei army?
No, Jiang Wei knew the exact size and petitioned for more reinforcements which barely arrived in time due to Huang Hao trusting in magic that told him they wouldn't reach the capital, thus the invasion wasn't a worry. Jiang Wei's defensive plan had worked for the most part, but the defection of Jiang Shu, the surrender of Jiangyou and Zhuge Zhan's loss at Mianzhu were not things he could account for and all piled up. Jiang Wei had successfully stopped Zhong Hui's 120k army in it's tracks at Jiange, but Deng Ai's clever maneuvering of unused pathways let him take Jiangyou by surprise. Zhuge Zhan further made tactical blunders in engaging Deng Ai on flat ground, losing his vanguard and then perishing at Mianzhu.

In a weird twist of irony, Huang Hao was right. Deng Ai never did reach the capital of Han. Liu Shan surrendered miles from the city. Deng Ai arrived to the Wei city of Chengdu.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Alright, what are the noob traps to avoid early on and in the early space stages.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1270114
Getting/keeping too many persuasion guys. Depending on your strategy you might want to get a full roster of a bunch of persuasion guys, but you'll never want more than at most two after the initial rush for countries.
Doing anything less than complete extermination of all alien presence on Earth. Killing alien operatives should be your number one priority in your strategy for the first decade. You should get alien detection fairly quickly and have a good investigation guy and a really good espionage guy by that time.
Building ships. You'll only need a few missile boats in the early 2030s to shoot down a ship for the techs and stuff that's gated behind it. After that you'll pretty much just want to wait until you've got late game weapons, drives, and hulls.
The Moon. You only want one mine to get as much stuff as you can. But even then depending on circumstances you may want to skip the Moon.
Building tier one space stations around Earth. The only exception is if you have good boost income and need to start killing aliens before the time you've unlocked tier two stations. Then you can go for some xenology stations for the bonus to alien detection.
Grabbing useless countries. You grab America for early science and long(ish) term military power. If you grab America you should fix its problems, maybe get its democracy up, make sure you keep enough investments in economy, welfare, and knowledge to keep it stable, and put as much as you can into increasing military tech. Also don't forget to bring all armies back to their home regions. Only go Europe if you're grabbing some good early science points and you plan to abandon them later or you're going for EU. Take all but the executive control points in whatever nations you can in order to lock other factions out of Europe. After grabbing enough and as you increase your CP cap then you can grab the French executive along with whatever other executive points you can to start unifying.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1270114
>>1270127
The whole time you're waiting to unify Europe you should be putting everything into MC in every country. For China you just pump knowledge as hard as you can. For India you do that but slightly delayed until you've fixed its issues. China and India are more long-term ones. Kazakhstan you want to take, set to zero spoils, and then coup. This takes it out of the Eurasian Union and allows you to get all of its boost for much less CP.
Not doing any spoils. You should have some country that you use for spoils to get plenty of early cash. You'll need it. Saudi Arabia is good for that.
Focusing too much on blobbing. The way the economy in this game works extremely heavily discourages blobbing. You only want to do it later to consolidate power, allow yourself to eat up more of the globe, and make your countries harder to break into (very important to remember the importance of clearing out alien life from Earth, especially xenofauna, lest you risk making a big nation only to have an alien enthrall one of your control points away from you which is effectively impossible for you to retake). Ideally you should grab nations that are going to be unified and make them pump MC, even if they need to start space programs from scratch.

threads.com:
A thread for discussing the best mod for HBS BattleTech.

Pros:
-Clans, clan tech and Elementals
-Vastly improved mechlab
-Huge library of new mechs
-Multiple lances and artillery

Cons
-Still coded in Garbage and prone to random crashes
-Probability fuckery including coded 'streak breakers' to stop you getting too lucky
-Maps aren't 'procedurally generated' like the kickstarter promised
-Stupid deployment system will often dump your lances into insanely shitty starting locations that no commander in their right mind would agree with

last_replies.com:
>>1264735
>Does your city break down if you gentrify too hard?
Short answer: no.
Long answer:
Residential demand is caused by job availability. All workplaces provide all classes of jobs (except high tech due to a bug, get the fix, it may not be the only bugged blackhole). You simply cannot make everyone rich or middle class even if you somehow only have CO and I-HT.
If you were to gentrify "too hard", you'd need to have multiple cities and some tax fiddling to discourage/encourage where the gentry live and where the poors do.
Your main concern is that the gentry probably won't pay for education spam on their own, but that won't necessarily matter. High education just affects manufacturing/high-tech demand unless guides and wikis are lying. All you need is land value for R$$ and R$$$ to put down roots, which elementary schools help with if you care not for parks, but I don't know what medium and high density "require" if it's not simply more land value.

Again, you may simply just struggle for tax. I've heard players complain before that I-HT doesn't pay the bills but that might just be due to a lack of job density whilst demanding better land value, service coverage and education.

It would be one of the Paradox Greats if the modding and the MP scene wasn't so fucking dead. Very little unique content/flavor. As somebody who plays both, I don't find it similar to Vic2 at all but I enjoy the underlying mechanics leagues more than EU4. In essence, the game is all about juggling population happiness and culture dynamics, happier pops are more productive pops, that's why you gotta build them shit and import goods into their region, while also doing stuff like using the "create colony" decision and building temples + theatres in population centres to speed up conversion and assimilation. One thing I fucking hate? You wanna take out Rome as soon as possible. Rome FUCKS in this game, if you don't take them out before they snowball you are going to be dealing with the most micro-intensive decade-long deathwar you've ever seen in Paradox games. Like seriously, the first thing you always have to do if you start anywhere near Europe is blob towards Italy, and it's honestly fucking obnoxious. People will recommend playing with the Invictus mod but idk I don't like some of their mechanical changes.

>>1268543
make factories that consume resources your country produces first.
build those factories in regions that produce the resource they consume for production bonuses.
you can make efficient chains of factories this way e.g. glass factories require coal, build them in a region that produces coal. liquor factories require grain and glass, build them in regions that produce grain and have a glass factory.
upgrade those factories as long as enough workers are a available until they meet the demand of their product or you don't have enough raw resources to keep them supplied at higher levels.
keep track of how much of the resource your country produces when upgrading or building a factory that produces it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1267940
>Thing that has been talked about to death in detail, no one has talked about it in detail
Longest mission timer off the top of my head in EG1 is 10 minutes, and it's one of the later ones. Every other mission in the game is between 30 seconds to four minutes and can be heavily reduced with just a few science minions. In EG2 the equivalent 'schemes' stretch way beyond any of that. EG2 merges the passive actions for the World map used to get money, with the progression/loot-gain missions from EG1. Money is teleported directly into the vault, so no one is carrying briefcases back and forth. As the devs want the game to have similar pacing to the first one(and seemingly for players to have even less control over that pacing), it means the naturally-occurring wait times of EG1 are translated into EG2 as extended timers.

Research in EG1 requires science minions to survey the base in their spare-time(they need time not doing anything else for this to happen), where they check-off a list of items as potential candidates. What you build in your base determines the possibilities. They feed these candidates into the research machine and the player chooses which to investigate and using what science equipment. The machine dispenses sample bottles which a science minion collects and uses to take samples from the object before bringing it back to the lab to use on the selected equipment. This will then succeed or fail depending on player choices and whether the minions were able to complete the jobs. This takes time, often a long time unless you have a lot of science minions, but it's long because those minions have to take an inventory object to a number of base objects and interact with them.

In EG2, it's long because it was long in EG1. The actual process itself has been removed, replaced with a time-gate: literal timers which you reduce by building blackboards or some shit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Is it worthwhile to look into any EG1 mods, or is the vanilla experience still the best?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1267993
You should at minimum get the Bonus Content. It's official content that was given for some promotion or other separately from the game, and has been distributed by fans as a mod for a long time, ever since the days of Evil Planet.
It includes a new Henchman (Colonel Blackheart), some objects for your base, and a new trap.

>Bonus Content
https://www.nexusmods.com/evilgenius/mods/16/

There's the Evil Planet Patch, which is a community-driven QoL improvement of the game from back during Evil Planet still existing.
It adds QoL features and fixes some issues with the game including potential exploits, but also changes some balance to the game by giving you way more freedom on how to build your base (allows Sentries to be built inside your base, allows all rooms to be built in both Hotel wings and underground base), and gives you a max hard cap of 150 Minions instead of the usual 100. Overall I think it's an improvement, and you can always restrain yourself from using the most game-changing parts since it does make some fixes and QoL additions that should've been in core game.

>EviL Planet Patch
https://www.nexusmods.com/evilgenius/mods/26

That's all you could possibly need, really. You could maybe want to use some retexture mod to change the coloring of your minion uniforms.
I remember spending hours on Paint editor and changing the textures of my minions to best suit my preferences, but that's entirely unnecessary and completely cosmetic.

threads.com:
Why are hexfags so fucking retarded they cannot see the forest for the trees?

See picrel for why why the "diagonal movement problem" hexfags try to ascribe to squares doesn't actually exist - because you are moving in tiles, not actual distance! It doesn't matter that you have moved 1.41 feet diagonally, when you would have moved only 1 foot orthgonaly, becasue YOU ARE NOT MOVING IN REAL DISTANCE, YOU ARE MOVING IN TILES.
See picrel, it takes the exact same amount of tiles to move from one corner to the next diagonally, that it takes to move from one corner to the next orthogonally.
Yes the real distance is larger, but that does not matter, since the game is structured in tiles, not real distance!

Hexxfagging is unirinically Reddit-style thinking - believing you are some sort of expert and can overturn years of time-tested methods because you have learned some arbitrary fun fact (in this case that distance from one center of a square to the center of diagonal square is larger than the distance to the center of a orthogonal square).

TL;DR: 1 tile = 1 tile, always

>>1264573
Invade the time bomb before it explodes. Switch to commie or fascist asap and justify a war on them. The US is slow to build up an army, when you catch them early, you catch them with their pants down and once your breach their front, you've won. The AI can't handle a frontline created by several divisions beelining for all major cities. It should just be encirclement after encirclement after that while the AI throws a shitton of untrained but equipped soldiers at you that are annoying and potentially dangerous, but can never close the gaps in the frontline. It's also how you win any other war where the enemy has lots of area but too few divisions (Portugal vs Spain, China, Tsarist Russia). Cavalry divisions supposedly help, but I'm too much of an autist to ever invest into an inferior version of things.

>>1254390
>You don't need trade routes for money, just get your cities connected and sell off your resources to your AI friends.
There is a point in the early game before markets are unlocked (unless you just absolutely rush them) where that simply isn't sufficient to maintain a surplus of gold. This especially applies when you are still building your road network and the connection bonus hasn't kicked in yet. At this particular point gold caravans are absolutely crucial. Once you have markets everywhere it's a little less pressing but food has never been a problem for me and it's always better to have more gold. I also generally don't sell my resources for money, I exhange the surplus luxury ones I have for luxuries I don't currently have, to keep my happiness up.
